content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of tissue scattered on the slide. The majority of the tissue appears to be adipose (fat) and fibroconnective tissue. There are several, at least three, distinct, darkly basophilic (purple) nodules that are highly suspicious for lymph nodes. My initial task would be to systematically examine each of these potential lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is one of the distinct, darkly stained nodules identified from the thumbnail view, which is characteristic of a lymph node. As part of a systematic cancer staging workup, every potential lymph node must be carefully examined at high magnification to look for evidence of metastasis. This appears to be the lymph node located on the far left of the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box highlights one of the well-circumscribed, basophilic nodules identified at low power. This is the typical appearance of a lymph node. As part of the cancer staging protocol, every identifiable lymph node must be meticulously examined at high magnification to rule out or confirm the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I am zooming in on this specific structure to assess its architecture and cellular components for any signs of malignancy. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to find positive lymph nodes. The green box highlights one of the distinct, darkly stained, ovoid structures that I identified at low power as a potential lymph node. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of every potential lymph node on the slide to assess its architecture and cellular composition for any evidence of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymph node tissue is composed of a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes. The cellular population appears to be predominantly small, dark lymphocytes, consistent with normal or reactive lymphoid tissue. In this specific field of view, I do not see any atypical glandular structures or nests of malignant epithelial cells to suggest metastasis. My impression is that this is a lymph node, likely negative for metastasis in this particular area, but I would need to scan the entire node to be certain.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms this is a lymph node embedded in mature adipose tissue. The node is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, round lymphocytes. The overall architecture appears preserved, although there are some areas of hemorrhage (red blood cells) and sinus congestion, suggesting reactive changes. Crucially, I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or nests of malignant cells. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms this is a lymph node surrounded by adipose tissue. The lymph node architecture appears preserved, showing multiple well-defined lymphoid follicles, which indicates a reactive process (follicular hyperplasia). The cellular population consists almost entirely of dense lymphocytes. I do not see any nests, glands, or clusters of atypical, large eosinophilic cells that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
